description: 1886 fractur, 1904 fraktur, from German Fraktur, Fractur, from Latin frāctūra (“breaking”, noun), from frangere (“to break”), past participle fractus. Compare English fracture, fraction. Doublet of fracture.

entries.meaning: (typography) A style of black letter type, used especially in Germany in the 16th to 20th centuries.
(US) A Pennsylvania German document style, incorporating watercolour illustration and fraktur lettering.
